Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this full research and development project, a team of learning scientists and media researchers at Education Development Center and SRI International will collaborate with educational media producers at WGBH to develop, test, and refine a curriculum supplement (a hands-on technology) that (1) promotes childrens' understanding of number (counting, comparing, and ordering) and fair sharing (equipartitioning); (2) uses interactive media on an emerging handheld platform (touch screen tablets), integrating new multi-touch activities with existing hands-on activities; (3) enhances opportunities for learning with interactive media through shared use with adult guides and peers; and (4) provides professional and technical support materials for preschool educators. The project investigates if and how engagement with activities in a media-rich curriculum supplement improves low-income young childrens' early learning of number and equipartitioning.

The project builds on sound research about learning trajectories to develop materials for fostering young childrens' learning. In addition, this project will generate new research findings about how engagement with activities in a media-rich curriculum supplement can improve low-income childrens' learning. The project uses use mixed methods (ethnographic observations and interviews and HLM analyses) to answer the research questions.

This project addresses a critical need to develop quality early childhood mathematics curriculum, particularly that aimed at low-income students. This project involves two important content areas. Both the content and the mode of delivery make major contributions to curriculum development and research. This project can provide much needed insights about how to effectively use technology for improving student learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Summary: The goal of the Next Generation Preschool Math (NGPM) Project was to create two curricular units to supplement any preexisting preschool math curriculum. NGPM materials included digital games on a touchscreen, tablet device and hands-on activities. These materials are designed to be integrated into existing preschool classroom practices in a developmentally appropriate manner. The resulting two units focused on subitizing and equipartitioning, important mathematics concepts that are typically excluded from preschool curricula.   Digital games (four per unit) and non-digital activities were used throughout the preschool day (e.g. circle time, learning centers, snack time, outdoors) in individual, pair, small- and whole-group settings. The units included self-leveling (adapts to the individual learner and provides scaffolding) and collaborative game (played by two plays, either peers or children and teachers) that include scaffolding to assist the learning process.  

Development and Theoretical Approach: The NGPM team consisted of learning scientists, curriculum developers, technology specialists and early childhood experts who collaboratively engaged in a research-based approach to design. The result was a set of activities that acted as a curricular activity system: this system incorporated the elements of preschool classrooms into the design of the activities themselves in order to facilitate teachers’ use of the materials and improve seamless integration of the tablet technology into the preschool classroom. In addition, the joint media engagement (JME) theoretical approach was used to invite teachers to mediate the learning process and encourage collaborative learning among students. Finally, the design-based implementation framework (DBIR) guided our design and development process that leveraged formative feedback to improve each iterative design phase.

The basis for activity design was the research on learning trajectories, which was instantiated in a “learning blueprint.” This blueprint specified the learning goals, and was used to develop the initial set of prototypes. These prototypes underwent formative testing and revision, a process we continued until a full set of activities was ready for pilot testing, further revision based on the pilot test, and a larger experimental study that assessed the impact on children’s learning. Our evidence-based curriculum design approach helped to ensure that the learning goals were maintained throughout each iteration of the activities.

Research Findings: The study randomized preschool classrooms (n=16) into two groups and compared classrooms using NGPM to a business-as-usual control group. Children’s mathematical knowledge was assessed individually at the beginning and end of the six-week implementation period. Children’s scores on the general math and NGPM content assessment were the same in the treatment and control group at the beginning of the study; however, by the end of the study preschool children in classrooms that used NGPM learned significantly more about the unit content by the end of the six week study. In addition, preschool teachers were able to effectively use the materials within the preschool classroom and reported being comfortable using the technology-based materials in their classrooms. Findings suggest that thoughtful integration of technology along with hands-on activities and teacher professional learning opportunities can improve positively impact children’s mathematics learning.

Project Outcomes: This project has resulted in two new digitally-infused preschool curricular units, a developmentally appropriate model for technology integration into preschool settings, a new approach to collaboration between researchers and developers, a new assessment of subitizing and equipartitioning that is developmentally appropriate for preschoolers, and professional development materials for preschool teachers. The units are freely available to anyone, as the Early Math with Gracie and Friends teachers guide, with all the hands-on activities, was published by the First 8 Studios at WGBH (first8studios.com) and the digital games were published as free apps in the Apple Store.

Intellectual Merit: This project has advanced understanding of how to design and implement digital and non-digital activities to scaffold young children’s learning of subitizing and equipartitioning. We generated a new design model and design principles that extend the design-based implementation research approach (DBIR; Penuel, et. al, 2011). This work builds on theories about facilitating early childhood math learning and instructional practices with technology affordances, all while utilizing a research-driven design processes. Our approach integrates research on learning trajectories, math practices, collaboration, and joint media engagement.  

Broader Impact: With preschool math knowledge a strong predictor of children’s later academic success, innovations in early math learning hold exceptional promise to address educational inequities. All NGPM apps have been Parents’ Choice Recommended or Approved Award winners. An app was featured on the Apple App Store, was named one of Common Sense Media’s Graphite’s “Best Ed Tech of 2014,” and was first in their “10 Best Math Tools for Elementary.” With over 1 million downloads to date, and with follow-on projects that build upon NGPM, this project has had a significant impact that continues to grow.
